abstract.p: Letter by Jeffrey D Friedlander of New York corporate counsel's office points out that heavy student debts keeps many young lawyers out of low-paying but high-esteem jobs in public service

block.p: Re ''New Lawyers Still Seek Public Service Jobs'' (news article, May 10):

One factor that makes recruiting law students to public service more challenging is the debt many students accrue in college and law school. While schools and employers have undertaken initiatives to forgive in part or delay the repayment of debt, these programs need to be expanded.

Despite the growing disparity in pay between public service positions and jobs in large law firms, the city's Law Department, like the organizations mentioned in the article, continues to be able to recruit talented and dedicated young lawyers from diverse backgrounds and law schools.

To paraphrase a favorite dictum of Edward I. Koch, there is nothing more rewarding than public service done well and honestly.
JEFFREY D. FRIEDLANDER1 New York, May 10, 2000
The writer is first assistant corporation counsel of the City of New York.
